author: Sophie Evans
title: 'Real-life Notebook' couple with dementia still deeply in love after 50 years - despite not always recognising each other
text:
Which diseases cause dementia? How do they affect the brain? Share this video Watch Next 
“My mum and dad are soul mates, without a doubt," said James, who works as a Regional Fundraising Officer for Alzheimer’s Research UK. 
"If my wife and I have half the marriage they’ve got, we’ll be doing just fine. 
“My parents did everything for my two sisters and me and put themselves second, they were a team. 
“These were the years that Ma and Pa were supposed to be able to relax and enjoy the fruits of their labours. 
"They should have been travelling, enjoying being grandparents, visiting family and friends. Instead, they are both in a care home. 
“They’ve both gone downhill a lot in the past year. Read More 
"Trying to get a smile out of my dad these days is incredibly difficult, the only time he really smiles is when he’s with Mum. 
“They still show that they’re in love with one another. 
"My mum is very short and my dad holds onto her forearm because he’s too tall to reach her hand, which we find very funny." 
But James said that, although there are "funny moments", seeing his parents suffer from the effects of dementia is "absolutely heartbreaking". 
"It’s hard not to talk about them in the past tense because they’ll never be the same people they were," he said. Chris and Hilary, from Dorset, were diagnosed with dementia within just two years of each other (Photo: alzheimersresearchuk.org) 
“Mum constantly asks where my dad is, even if he’s standing next to her, and she won’t always recognise that that’s him. 
"But there is a constant familiarity there, even if she doesn’t know it’s really him she’ll hold his hand and rest her head on his shoulder. 
“They loved walking and would walk for miles and miles, happily taking in where they were and enjoying the time together. 
"We try to take them to the beach and other places where they can walk so they can still do that together. Read More How kind-hearted strangers fulfilled dying wish of parents who passed away after heartbreaking picture 
“As time goes on they will have to have separate bedrooms, and will forget who each other are altogether. 
"This breaks my heart, but I know that somewhere inside them they’ll always remember their love for one another.” 
James’s parents have been together for more than 50 years, since 1966. 
When they first became a couple, they were aged just 22 and 19. 
The inseparable pair met when Hilary moved from Dublin to London and visited a post office where Chris was working. 
She said Chris, who later worked at Barclays bank, had short-changed her. In some ways, the pair's love story is reminiscent of the hit 2004 film, The Notebook 
But adamant he had not, Chris asked her out on a date to diffuse the situation. 
The couple married in 1969 and had three children together – Joanna in 1970, Victoria in 1971, and James in 1979. 
In 2007, Hilary fell down the stairs and had a brain aneurysm, which led her to develop vascular dementia, which she was diagnosed with just a few years later. 
She would repeatedly go missing after becoming lost and confused. 
Not long after, in 2012, the family were told that Chris had Alzheimer’s. 
The couple lived in Lytchett Matravers in Dorset from 1984 until 2014. 
They then moved to Parkstone, Dorset, to be right next to their two daughters, before they had to go into full-time care a year ago. Read More Anorexic teenager who lived off diet of water, diet coke and energy drinks illustrates book about beating her demons 
Devastatingly, Chris recently ripped up some treasured love letters, written between his wife and him in the 1960s. 
He had treasured the letters for decades, but destroyed them through frustration with what was happening to him and Hilary. 
They are now being pieced back together by the pensioner's devoted family, who are looking after the documents for him. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
